_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

The facilities overall approach to safety is ensuring that the equipment used at the facility is maintained and updated as required by each process.  The facility is also committed to providing its employees with the skills necessary to safely handle the chemicals used at the site.  Dovray Grain and feed believes that its good relationship with its neighbors and the surrounding agricultural community is vital to success and would not jeopardize the communities safety over profit.

For both the anhydrous ammonia and the propane storage tanks, the tanks and associated piping are visually inspected and maintained to ensure the tank and its components are in good condition and they do not develop defects which could compromise the tanks integrity.  Both tanks contain manual shut-off valves which will stop the flow out of the piping if a rupture in any of the connected hosing should develop.  The anhydrous tank is also equipped with automatic valves which will shut off the flow if a pipe break were to occur.  The anhydrous ammonia tank is also equipped with break away piping  which will prevent damage to the tank and loss of substantial product if a transfer tank is not disconnected prior to moving away from the loading area.   The applicator tanks for the anhydrous operations are also inspected regularly and maintained to prevent releases.

Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled:

Dovray Grain and Feed has processes present on the site for anhydrous ammonia and liquid propane which require the facility to complete a Risk Management Plan (RMP)  

The facility contains propane storage for grain drying in a 12,000 gallon tank at the eastern end of the facility.  The propane stored at the site is not available for re-sale and is utilized on the premises.  

The facility contains anhydrous ammonia for resale.  The anhydrous ammonia is stored in a 18,000 gallon tank on the western end of the fa

cility.  Facility personnel are responsible for transferring the anhydrous ammonia to transfer tanks which are used in conjunction with injection equipment to inject the product into the ground for use as a fertilizer.

Worst Case Release Scenarios and Alternative Release Scenarios:

Propane
The worst case scenario for the propane stored on the site would be a tank rupture releasing all 44,352 pounds of propane and the subsequent ignition of the flammable propane resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  This worst case release scenario would have an impact of approximately 0.3 miles from the tank source.  The EPAs RMP comp program was used to determine the worst case scenario impacts.

The alternative release scenario chosen for the propane storage was a release for two minutes from piping coming from the tank and the subsequent ignition of the propane resulting in a vapor cloud fire.  The alternative release scenario would have an impact extending to approximately 0.1 miles from the pipe rupture.  The EPAs RMP comp program was used to determine the alternative release scenario. 

Anhydrous Ammonia
The worst case scenario for the anhydrous ammonia stored and handled on the site would be a tank rupture releasing 84,118 pounds of anhydrous ammonia which would create a liquid spill and vaporization.  The worst case scenario would have an impact of approximately 3.3 miles from the tank source.  The EPAs RMP comp program was used to determine the worst case scenario impacts.

The alternative release scenario chosen for the anhydrous ammonia storage and handling was a pipe leak for two minutes from the tank resulting in a smaller release of anhydrous ammonia and vaporization.  The alternative release scenario would have an impact extending to approximately 0.42 miles from the pipe leak.  An EPA reference table was used to determine this alternative release scenario.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps:

The facility complies with

OSHA (29CFR 1910.111) for anhydrous ammonia and complies with NFPA 58 the LP Gas Code.

Preventing a release by ensuring equipment is maintained is our best prevention. 

In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release our first steps will include, calling 911 which will in turn notify the local fire department.  The processes utilized to prevent injuries from the release will be to evacuate residences downwind of the release which could be impacted by the anhydrous ammonia vapors.  The fire department will utilize water to minimize the amount of vaporization.  Water is also the first means of first aid for persons that come into contact with the anhydrous ammonia.

In the event of a propane release one of our first steps will also include calling 911.  The fire department has the training and equipment to respond to propane releases.  Evacuation of affected residents, stopping the release, and water curtains will be the primary actions taken to mitigate the release.

Five Year Accident History:

The site has not had a release of propane or anhydrous ammonia within the last five years which resulted in any injury to site personnel or to the residents of Dovray.

Emergency Response Program: 

All of the sites emergency procedures are conducted with the local volunteer fire department.  In case of an accident at the site, the local fire department would be called upon for assistance.  The facility personnel are trained in the proper handling of the anhydrous ammonia equipment and in basic first aid procedures in case of contact with the anhydrous ammonia.  Water tanks for utilizing in case of accidental contact with the anhydrous ammonia are present adjacent to the 18,000 gallon tank and water is present on all of the transfer tanks.

Propane is not handled or transferred by facility personnel.  The facility personnel are familiar with the location of the manual shut-off valves on the propane tank if a leak were to develop in the piping.  The transfer of propane to the t

ank is performed by the transport company from whom the propane is purchased.  The Dovray facility is responsible for ensuring that the tank and piping is in sound condition.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

We have no immediate plans for changes at the facility to improve our overall safety.  Our spring start-up of anhydrous ammonia handling will include in-house refresher training for employees on proper equipment handling procedures and safety.
